Project Number: 44308  
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA)  
December 2010 
 
 
 
Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka: Support 
for Planning and Policy Formulation, Phase 1 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  S. Rahman, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  R. Vokes, Sri Lanka Resident Mission (SLRM), SARD 
   
Team leader  N. Rao, Country Lead Economist, SLRM, SARD

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  With the end in 2009 of the war, which lasted about 3 decades, the Government of 
Sri Lanka is focusing on measures for improving economic management, accelerating economic 
growth, and rapidly reducing remaining poverty. While medium-term economic prospects are 
encouraging, the uncertain global financial and economic situation has made policy choices 
more  complex  and  challenging.  Sri  Lanka  needs  to  undertake  policy  reforms,  strengthen 
institutions to increase the resilience of the economy, and adapt its economic management and 
planning  process  to  an  uncertain  external  economic  environment.  Given  the  longstanding 
engagement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) with Sri Lanka, the government approached 
ADB for technical assistance (TA) for improving planning and policy formulation. During the 
country programming mission in June 2010, ADB discussed the scope and modality of the TA1 
with the government. The request has strong justification as the government has displayed its 
commitment  by  undertaking  macroeconomic  stabilization  measures  under  the  International 
Monetary Fund’s standby arrangement and is now determined to carry the reform process 
further  by  strengthening  the  planning  system  and  evaluating  different  policy  options  for 
addressing  constraints  to  overall  economic  efficiency  and  medium-  to  long-term  economic 
prospects. ADB’s Sri Lanka Resident Mission undertook a fact-finding mission in July 2010 and 
an agreement was reached with the government on the scope of the TA, its impact, outcomes, 
outputs, and implementation and financing arrangements (Appendix 1). 
   
II.  ISSUES   
2.  Since the end of the war in 2009, the Sri Lankan economy has the potential to grow 
rapidly (at least around 8% per annum) and alleviate poverty, which is currently estimated at 
15%. Economic growth has picked up markedly in 2010 and is projected to be around 7%; 
inflation is projected to be around 6.5%. The government is taking measures to reduce the fiscal 
deficit to more sustainable levels. Foreign exchange reserves have increased dramatically over 
the last 2 years, and Sri Lanka is able to raise money in international capital markets on 
considerably improved terms. With improved planning and policy reforms, economic growth can 
be  accelerated.  Conversely,  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  potential  could  be 
compromised  by  ineffective  planning  and  lack  of  policy  reforms.  Policy  choices  and  their 
implementation  have  become  complex  and  challenging  in  an  uncertain  global  economic 
environment.  
 
3.   Sri Lanka needs to reorient its policy framework to suit the requirements of a middle-
income country in which the private sector is expected to play an increasingly important role. 
The government will continue to create an enabling environment for greater participation of the 
private sector. As the economy becomes more integrated with the external economy through 
both trade and capital flows, the following issues will take center stage in policy debates: 
financial sector development, management of capital flows, macroeconomic management with a 
relatively open capital account of the balance of payments, developing appropriate regulatory 
and supervisory systems, and overall flexibilities of policies. Some key policy issues that need to 
be analyzed and better understood are (i) a policy mix to maintain domestic demand if industrial 
countries continue to experience sluggish growth in the medium term—a plausible scenario in 
the current environment; (ii) what needs to be done to divert exports from industrial countries 
(where demand could be sluggish) to emerging market economies; (iii) diversification of the 
export composition; (iv) monetary and exchange rate policies if interest rates remain low in 
industrial countries and speculative capital continues to flow to Sri Lanka for short-term capital 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 October 2010.

2   
gains; (v) sequencing of financial sector liberalization, regulation, and supervision, taking into 
account the lessons of the global financial crisis; (vi) assessment of systemic risks in the 
financial  sector;  (vii)  policies  to  strengthen  fiscal  management  so  that  public  debt  can  be 
contained at prudent levels; (viii) policies that encourage balanced growth between sectors in 
the economy, specifically policies to revive the manufacturing sector; (ix) a sound framework for 
encouraging  public–private  partnership,  especially  for  financing  infrastructure  development; 
(x) balanced development of the rural sector, which still provides sustenance to a majority of the 
population; (xi) addressing issues related to climate change; and (xii) policies that encourage 
inclusive growth so that benefits of growth are more widely shared.  
 
4.  Enhancing understanding of these policy issues will require sound analytical work to be 
undertaken, drawing on the experience of other countries, and assessing their effectiveness in 
the Sri Lankan context. Various options will need to be examined. This will facilitate public 
debate  on  the  policy  options,  which  will  increase  awareness  and  encourage  stakeholder 
participation in policy formulation. This process will help build consensus within Sri Lanka on a 
policy framework for promoting socially inclusive and sustainable economic growth.  
 
5.  ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2009–20112 focuses on two pillars: (i) strengthening 
the investment climate, and (ii) achieving socially inclusive development. With the end of the 
war, these two pillars have become the focus of the government’s policy initiatives. The current 
business  environment  requires  significant  improvement.  Sri  Lanka  is  ranked  105  among 
183 countries  in  ease  of  doing  business,  behind  Pakistan  (ranked  85)  and  the  Maldives 
(ranked 87).3 The government is keen to improve the business climate and increase private 
sector participation in the development process. It is also attempting to foster inclusive growth 
by investing public funds in poorer parts of the country. The challenge is to develop a policy 
framework that attracts private investment in the lagging regions to accelerate the pace of 
balanced  economic  development.  The  TA  will  assist  the  government  in  this  exercise  by 
providing resource persons who will examine different policy options; establish policy reform 
milestones; and encourage public debate on key policy issues through publications, seminars, 
and workshops. 
 
6.  Policy makers face different situations that require periodic changes and calibration of 
economic policies. They also need to work within the planning framework so that economic 
policies can be formulated to meet the medium- to long-term goals of the government. Moreover, 
policy makers require assistance on a large number of issues, so it is difficult to predict the 
ultimate scope of TA that aims to strengthen planning and policy formulation. Taking these 
factors into account, this TA is Phase 1 in the process of providing continuing support to the 
government. Phase 2 of the TA is planned for late 2011. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.   The impact of the TA will be better policy formulation on a range of economic issues 
confronting  Sri  Lanka,  so  that  medium-term  economic  growth  accelerates  and  poverty  is 
reduced rapidly. The outcome of the TA will be wider discussion and awareness of policy issues 
within the country. It will also encourage participation of stakeholders in policy formulation and 
hence facilitate broad support for the policies. The policy makers will be able to examine 
                                                 
2 ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: Sri Lanka, 2009–2011. Manila. 
3 World Bank. 2010. Doing Business 2010: Reforming through difficult times. Washington, DC.

3
international best practice policy options and adopt those that suit Sri Lanka. The TA will also 
provide opportunities for Sri Lanka to tap regional and international expertise through resource 
persons  for  seminars  and  discussions,  to  improve  economic  policy  formulation  and 
implementation in Sri Lanka. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The proposed TA will provide resources for more informed policy making by establishing 
a knowledge base through research and analytical studies. It will also facilitate wider discussion 
of policy issues nationally, and provide the government with a forum to elicit views and insights 
of regional and international experts through seminars and workshops. The scope of the TA will 
cover (i) providing assistance for policy research and analysis, data collection, and information 
dissemination; and (ii) creating a forum for policy dialogue and analysis through a partnership 
with the key stakeholders. The TA will help improve the government’s economic policy reform 
agenda by evaluating policy reforms and providing feedback on implementation, recommending 
new  ideas  and  policy  options  to  policy  makers,  assisting  policy  makers  in  analyzing  and 
responding  to  regional  and  global  economic  challenges,  and  fostering  constructive  policy 
dialogue between the government and research institutions within the country and in the region.  
 
9.  The main output of the TA will be five seminars and conference on policy issues facing 
Sri Lanka.  National,  international,  and  regional  resource  persons  will  prepare  background 
discussion papers on these issues and provide alternative policy options for discussion at the 
seminars and conferences. Key policy makers, academics, representatives of development 
partners, and other stakeholders will be invited to participate in the seminars and conferences. 
The other output of the TA will be the publication of a number of books and papers on policy 
issues,  and  documented  proceedings  of  seminars  and  conferences.  To  follow  up  on  the 
seminars and conferences, ADB will hold continuous dialogue with the policy makers and assist 
them with the sequencing and implementation of policies. ADB will also use the TA to give 
extensive press and media coverage on the major themes discussed in the seminars and 
conferences.  
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-IV).  It  is  proposed  that  ADB  provide  $300,000  equivalent  and  the  government  will 
contribute $53,000 equivalent in administrative support.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The TA will be jointly administered by the Ministry of Finance and Planning and ADB Sri 
Lanka Resident Mission. The National Planning Department of the Ministry of Finance and 
Planning will be the executing agency.  
 
12.  A  steering  committee  will  be  formed  to  facilitate  implementation  of  the  TA.  The 
committee will be co-chaired by the secretary (or his designated representative) of the Ministry 
of Finance and Planning, and the country director of ADB Sri Lanka Resident Mission. Other 
members of the committee will include a representative from the National Planning Department, 
a representative from the External Resources Department, the head of research of the Central 
Bank of Sri Lanka, the executive director of the Institute for Policy Studies, the head of the 
Presidential  Tax  Commission  and  member  of  the  Advisory  Council  on  Economics  to  the 
President  of  Sri  Lanka,  and  two  staff  of  ADB  Sri  Lanka  Resident  Mission.  Government

4   
departments, most notably the Ministry of Finance and Planning and the Ministry of Economic 
Development,  will  suggest  the  research  topics.  The  steering  committee  will  evaluate  the 
importance  of  the  proposed  research  project  and  will  determine  the  scope  of  research, 
requirements of consultant inputs (both domestic and international), and draw up the terms of 
reference for the consultants. The steering committee will review the consultants’ outputs and 
will determine the most effective method of disseminating the findings of the studies—either 
through publications or seminar and/or conference. 
  
13.  The TA will require the support of both international and national consultants to prepare 
papers on topics identified by the steering committee. The TA envisages the services of five 
international and 10 national individual consultants for preparing the research papers. The 
international consultants will provide 20 person-months of inputs and the national consultants 
will provide 40 person-months. In addition, the TA will require the services of 10 international 
and 20 national resource persons who will attend the seminars and conferences and present 
papers on country-specific experiences. The consultants will be recognized experts in their 
fields and the resource persons will be senior policy makers from countries in the region and 
reputed academics. Recruitment of consultants will be in line with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will commence in January 2011 
and be implemented over 2 years. Disbursement under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
14.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for Support for Planning and Policy Formulation, 
Phase 1, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   International Consultants (2 person-months each) 
1.  International consultants will be engaged to write papers on policy issues identified by 
the government and endorsed by the technical assistance (TA) steering committee.  
  
2.   Responsibilities under the TA will include but not be limited to  
(i)  in-depth  research  on  a  policy  issue  relevant  to  Sri  Lanka,  identified  by  the 
steering committee; 
(ii)  drawing on international experiences and developing a research paper on the 
identified issue; and 
(iii)  writing a research paper suitable for publication. 
 
3.   The following outputs will be expected: 
(i)  a research paper on an identified issue, meeting standards for publication; and 
(ii)  applying international experience and best-practice knowledge on the topic in 
writing the paper. 
 
B.  National Consultants (2 person-months each) 
4.  National consultants will be engaged to write papers on policy issues identified by the 
government and endorsed by the TA steering committee.  
  
5.   Responsibilities under the TA will include but not be limited to  
(i)  in-depth  research  on  a  policy  issue  relevant  to  Sri  Lanka,  identified  by  the 
steering committee; 
(ii)  drawing on in-depth understanding of Sri Lanka and developing a research paper 
on the identified issue; and 
(iii)  writing a research paper suitable for publication. 
 
6.   The following outputs will be expected: 
(i)  a research paper on an identified issue, meeting standards for publication; and 
(ii)  applying expert knowledge on the topic and the Sri Lankan context in writing the 
paper.
